dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey everyone, and welcome back to the show. So, um, we've got some pretty concerning news today, building on what we've heard about COVID-19's long-term effects. A new study, peer-reviewed, just came out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey everyone, and welcome back to the show. So, um, we've got some pretty concerning news today, building on what we've heard about C O V I D-nineteen's long-term effects. A new study, peer-reviewed, just came out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In another worrying set of findings for the long-term impact of Covid-19, a new peer reviewed study has confirmed reported links between psychiatric illness and Covid-19...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? What's the, uh, what's the topline there? 'Cause, you know, we've been hearing a lot of snippets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? What's the, uh, what's the topline there? Cause, you know, we've been hearing a lot of snippets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, this one confirms a link between psychiatric illness and COVID-19. They found nearly one in five COVID patients developed a mental illness within three months of testing positive. That's, like, a pretty significant number.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, this one confirms a link between psychiatric illness and C O V I D-nineteen. They found nearly one in five C O V I D patients developed a mental illness within three months of testing positive. That's, like, a pretty significant number.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...with nearly one in five Covid-19 patients developing a mental illness within three months of testing positive for the virus...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, one in five. That's... that's a lot. And, uh, what kind of mental illnesses are we talking about here? Is it, like, a broad spectrum?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, one in five. That's... that's a lot. And, uh, what kind of mental illnesses are we talking about here? Is it, like, a broad spectrum?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, the researchers, from the University of Oxford, they looked at 69 million health records, which is huge. They found anxiety, depression, and insomnia were the most elevated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the researchers, from the University of Oxford, they looked at sixty nine million health records, which is huge. They found anxiety, depression, and insomnia were the most elevated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By examining the health records of 69 million people in the U.S., including over 62,000 Covid-19 patients, researchers from the University of Oxford and NIHR Oxford Health Biomedical Research Centre found evidence that Covid-19 increases a persons risk of developing psychiatric illness...with rates of anxiety, depression and insomnia most elevated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] So not, like, new psychotic disorders then, like schizophrenia, but more on the anxiety-depression spectrum?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So not, like, new psychotic disorders then, like schizophrenia, but more on the anxiety-depression spectrum?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers said they found no clear signs of newly diagnosed psychotic disorders in Covid-19 patients, which includes schizophrenia...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They said no clear signs of *newly diagnosed* psychotic disorders, which is, uh, good, I guess. But they did note a higher likelihood of relapse for patients already living with those conditions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They said no clear signs of newly diagnosed psychotic disorders, which is, uh, good, I guess. But they did note a higher likelihood of relapse for patients already living with those conditions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers said they found no clear signs of newly diagnosed psychotic disorders in Covid-19 patients, which includes schizophrenia, though they did note the higher likelihood of relapse in patients already living with the conditions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, that makes sense. But there was another unexpected finding in this study too, right? Something about pre-existing conditions?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, that makes sense. But there was another unexpected finding in this study too, right? Something about pre-existing conditions?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes! This was, like, really striking to me. They found that people with a pre-existing psychiatric illness were 65% more likely to be diagnosed with COVID-19 themselves, even when they accounted for other risk factors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes! This was, like, really striking to me. They found that people with a pre-existing psychiatric illness were sixty five percent more likely to be diagnosed with C O V I D-nineteen themselves, even when they accounted for other risk factors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...those with pre-existing mental conditions being 65% more likely to be diagnosed with Covid-19, even accounting for other risk factors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Sixty-five percent more likely? That's, um, that's a huge jump. So having a mental health condition actually makes you more vulnerable to *getting* COVID in the first place?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sixty-five percent more likely? That's, um, that's a huge jump. So having a mental health condition actually makes you more vulnerable to getting C O V I D in the first place?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: That's what Dr. Max Taquet, one of the researchers, said. He thinks having a psychiatric disorder should actually be added to the official list of COVID-19 risk factors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what Doctor Max Taquet, one of the researchers, said. He thinks having a psychiatric disorder should actually be added to the official list of C O V I D-nineteen risk factors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Max Taquet, one of the researchers, said the unexpected finding needs investigation, recommending that having a psychiatric disorder should be added to the list of risk factors for Covid-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So it's not just a consequence, it's also, like, a precursor. It really highlights how interconnected, uh, our mental and physical health are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So it's not just a consequence, it's also, like, a precursor. It really highlights how interconnected, uh, our mental and physical health are.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And, you know, this study just, like, really underscores the magnitude of the mental health crisis we're facing, especially compounded by everything else we know about long COVID, like the physical symptoms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And, you know, this study just, like, really underscores the magnitude of the mental health crisis we're facing, especially compounded by everything else we know about long C O V I D, like the physical symptoms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While there have been studies and reports warning of an impending mental health crisis... the scope of this research really highlights the magnitude of the problem. It is compounded by a growing body of evidence looking at the long-term impacts of a Covid-19 infection on the body...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the rashes, the COVID toes... all that stuff. It's, uh, a lot for people to deal with long-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the rashes, the C O V I D toes... all that stuff. It's, uh, a lot for people to deal with long-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...with rashes and Covid toes both symptoms of long Covid, which can affect the body for months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Paul Harrison, who led the study, he said the findings validate worries that COVID survivors will be at greater risk of mental health problems. He said services need to be ready to provide care, especially since these results are probably underestimates.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Paul Harrison, who led the study, he said the findings validate worries that C O V I D survivors will be at greater risk of mental health problems. He said services need to be ready to provide care, especially since these results are probably underestimates.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Paul Harrison, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Oxford and leader of the study, said the findings validate worries that Covid-19 survivors will be at a greater risk of mental health problems. Services need to be ready to provide care, especially since our results are likely to be underestimates of the actual number of cases, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, 'cause not everyone, uh, gets diagnosed or seeks help. So the actual numbers are likely even higher.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, cause not everyone, uh, gets diagnosed or seeks help. So the actual numbers are likely even higher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And he's calling for urgent research to investigate causes and identify new treatments, which, you know, we definitely need.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And he's calling for urgent research to investigate causes and identify new treatments, which, you know, we definitely need.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We urgently need research to investigate the causes and identify new treatments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's a, uh, really complex and evolving situation. Thanks for breaking that down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's a, uh, really complex and evolving situation. Thanks for breaking that down.
